tweet: The price of gold is down 11% over the past twelve months.  The S&P 500 is up 27% over the past twelve months.  Bitcoin is up 467% over the past twelve months. Great dispersions often precede great reversions. We shall see.

U.S. GDP looks to be down 15%ish, unannualized, from its peak. SPX is presently down a similar amount from its peak. Ergo (and I over simplify to make a valid point) stocks now are back to the Feb 19th highs from a valuation perspective. “In Fed We Trust” is all the buyers have.
I can see the S&P 500 making it to around 2700 on this snap back.
Has the VIX, sometimes called the S&P fear index, ever sustained this long above 40? I don’t think so. Yet the bull/bear investor surveys show a lot of complacency.
Where did the Bitcoin real-time window go on CNBC? Better question: why was it there in the 1st place? AAPL window next after guidance bomb?
Well we’re pretty close to year-end and stocks are down (FB down hard), yields are up and Bitcoin below 5,000. Check, check, check and check
AAPL down 7% on earnings report.  “Et tu, Brute? Then fall, Caesar!”
Nothing like wiping out the entire strong YTD gain on SPX to make the “interest rates are rising for the right reasons” narrative to vanish.
SPX down 6.5% from high on closing basis with Treasury yields down < 4 bp on closing basis. Not looking good for “risk parity” strategies.
Big long positioning in $. Massive short positioning in US Treasuries. SPX back at highs on diminishing momentum.  Boom narrative post peak.
Only surprise in FB bad guidance was how obvious it was to happen yet so many chose not to see it. 90+% of 1Q earnings were B4 the  trouble.
The S&P 500’s dividend yield is now lower than the yield on a three month US Treasury Bill.
Guy on stage after me at Sohn 2day told me he’s short FB since Jan. Then on TV he said he disagrees with the short call. Both can’t be true.
